messages.content:
Very useful info, thank you.
A question on Hybrid approach from the article:

- So we have a smart contract that secured by PoS, and using this contract we for some reason have locked an ERC20 that secured by Plasma. If PoS layer is corrupted, will user be able to freely claim the ERC20 on Ethereum even though it was locked in the PoS contract?

@NicholasND yes you need to be careful while taking the hybrid approach. If the Plasma token is locked in a PoS contract, it might not be exitable. You can do mix and match of Plasma tokens and contracts in the same DApp, but contract interactions can be tricky. Better to go with one model.

Thank you. Just read recently on the predicates concept, this is such a huge achievement. 
Can you pls give more details on, is it possible to code a predicate for any solidity contract? If no, what the constraints could be?

> Can you pls give more details on, is it possible to code a predicate for any solidity contract? If no, what the constraints could be?
It is possible for a large variety of contracts subject to Ethereum gas constraints
> Would it be possible to implement someting like uniswap / kyberswap liquidity protocols? Only only easier swaps are possible.
They are certainly possible.
Although require a slight learning curve tbh
Here's a sample swap predicate - https://github.com/maticnetwork/contracts/blob/develop/contracts/root/predicates/MarketplacePredicate.sol

messages.content: @Rahul | Polygon ( Matic ) thanks 👍

@Rahul | Polygon ( Matic ) @Anurag about mint in matic if for example, an user on ethereum have 10 tokens "deposit" using matic.js in matic via erc20 approval process.. in the matic network will be mint more 10 tokens, when the user request withdrawal on the ethereum will be 20 tokens ? how matic can mint or transfer on ethereum erc20 contract ?

You can either mint on matic or ethereum. You can mint tokens on both the networks. Its because if we do so, there would be a mismatch in the totalSupply and the balances of the token on the two networks. 

So for now, when you deposit your tokens using matic.js, your tokens get locked in a particular contract on ethereum and then they get minted on your account on matic. When you withdraw from matic, your tokens on matic are burnt and the tokens that were locked previously are refunded to your account on ethereum.
yes so if we mint more tokens in matic than locked in ethereum will fail right?
for the withdrawal like the example i give above
@Rahul | Polygon ( Matic )

Only the same amount of tokens that you lock on ethereum will be minted on matic. The mint function on the matic chain token contract can be called only by a particular contract called ChildChain. ChildChain contract is triggered internally when a deposit happens. Hence there is no chance of more tokens getting minted on matic chain
hm ok
GG @Helder Pinto, you just advanced to level 1!
@Rahul | Polygon ( Matic ) for the plasma model and PoS bridge model is the same logic for deposit right?
we can't mint more in matic than "locked tokens"
Yeah, the mechanism is same. The contracts differ.
And yes we cant mint more than "locked tokens" in matic.

@Rahul | Polygon ( Matic ) sorry for my confusion 😄 let me reformulate the question, so «"When you withdraw from matic, your tokens on matic are burnt and the tokens that were locked previously are refunded to your account on ethereum."»  that happens if we mint more in matic that locked tokens for matic in ethereum network. My question is when the user will withdraw this tokens the transaction fails ? or the tokens are burned and the refunded tokens is equal to the total available (in ethereum "locked tokens") and the remaining will be lost.   simple e.g. userA on ethereum lock 10 tokens, and matic will only have this "locked tokens", if on matic we deposit more 10 on userA, the user will have 20, so when the userA withdrawal what happens? the transaction fail ? tokens are burned and on ethereum will be only 10 tokens (total locked available amount) ?

Ok. So if the user recieved matic token from.some other user on matic chain, then he can withdraw that total amount to ethereum. 

So in ur case
UserA deposits 10
10 gets locked on ethereum 
UserA gets 10 on matic. 
UserB sends 10 to userA on matic. 
Now userA has balance 20
UserA now burns his 20 tokens
He can then finally withdraw 20 on ethereum. 

Locking is not mapped to a specific user address. Locking is mapped to the token address only.

The equillibrium is maintained always. 
UserB was able to send 10tokens to userA only because he too had locked it on ethereum previously.
my case is about deposit, switch this example "UserB sends 10 to userA on matic."  line to "deposit 10 to userA". when the userA burns 20 in ethereum only have 10 what happens ?
Yes. if the user burns 20 tokens, the user can withdraw 20 tokens.
if the user has a balance of 20 on matic chain, it is ensured that the locked token balance is sufficient for the user to withdraew

GG @fergarrui, you just advanced to level 2!

btw I used hardhat flattener successfully to verify a contract in Matic.
The error you're getting about `SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT`  is a known issue with hardhat flattener: https://github.com/nomiclabs/hardhat/issues/1050

You need to remove all duplicated lines or simply all of them (if you don't mind it) with something like:

```
sed -i 's/SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT//g' contracts/<your flat contract>.sol
```

I have successfully verified a contract with it as well, but not one with this error. I keep getting the "bytecode didn't match" after removing the lines. What else can I try here?
I checked out the exact commit used to compile the contract and did an `npm ci` install before doing the flattener too just to make sure nothing progressed.

you need to remove the lines before compiling and deploying, solidity appends a hash at the end that will change even if you remove comments, so if you already deployed and then you're trying to verify a modified source, the bytecode will be different (because of the hash appended by solidity)

so I would:

1- flat your contract `npx hardhat flatten contracts/YourContract.sol > contracts/YourContractFlat.sol`
2- remove the SPDX lines, you can leave one, or just remove all of them with: `sed -i 's/SPDX-License-Identifier: MIT//g' contracts/YourContractFlat.sol`
3- make sure everything compiles before deploying: `npx hardhat compile` 

If you don't get an error compiling and everything goes well, then go and deploy the contract in Matic and then verify the source code, it should work

1) go to the token address
2) connect Metamask
3) go to the write section of the contract
3) At the approval method,  input your address, then the address of the contract you gave approval to, then 0 for the allowance.
